Title:
Incidence and phylogenetic analysis of Armillaria spp.
associated with root disease in peach orchards in the State of Mexico,
Mexico
Abstract:
Incidence of peach [Prunus persica (L.) Batsch] tree
mortality attributed to Armillaria root disease was assessed from 2009
to 2011 in 15 orchards in the state of Mexico, Mexico. Incidence
increased gradually every year of assessment, reaching average values of
9.7, 16.9 and 22.9% tree mortality and 23.3, 27.3 and 31.5% affected
area of the orchards during 2009, 2010, and 2011, respectively. The
cultivars âNemaguardâ and âCriollos of La Goletaâ, used as rootstock in
the region, were susceptible to the disease. To identify species of
Armillaria isolated from infected peach trees, three nuclear rDNA
regions (partial 5.8S-ITS2; D1, D2, and D3 domains LSU; partial 3â
LSU-IGS1) and translation elongation factor-1Î± (tef-1Î±) gene were
sequenced and compared with sequences of known Armillaria species. DNA
sequence analysis from 41 Armillaria isolates revealed that five
isolates (10.2%) were A. mellea, and eight isolates (16.3%) were A.
gallica. DNA sequences from the remaining 28 isolates (74.3%) showed no
close similarity to Armillaria sequences in GenBank, and apparently
represent an undescribed Armillaria species. This undescribed species
was the most widely distributed in the region of study. Phylogenetic
analysis of the LSU and tef-1Î± regions shows that the undescribed
species is quite distinct from other Armillaria species reported in
North America.
